content: @T-release meeting!
alright
@DPC anything urgent on triage?
nothing urgent need to look into the open prs
ok
let's move on into a bit of release discussion/retro

the first thing I wanted to mention is that I haven't pushed through the new beta or bootstrap changes on master; currently dealing with some problems on CI https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/pull/86413
I'm hoping to get both squared away today, though
It doesnâ€™t seem like ::BITS broke the world, so that was good.
other than that, I think generally there were no problems with the release that were prominently visible to the world -- though definitely some problems we can identify internally
@Pietro Albini mentioned (and I agree) that this release, like 1.52 and several of the past releases too I think, though in different ways had several last minute fixes and patches due to discoveries
it's not clear to me that we can do too much about this; there was some discussion of pushing the release back a little
rather, push the testing build earlier, I thought?
yeah that was my understanding too
er yeah
I meant the prerelease, sorry
I think having the pre-release come out wed the week before could alleviate the "last minute fixes" problem

I do think some reminder to ask for beta testing would help too -- even if we're not asking for the specifically-new beta yet. more like "please also consider adding the beta channel to your regular testing routing, as it's easier on everyone to catch problems early!"

Pietro Albini said:

I think having the pre-release come out wed the week before could alleviate the "last minute fixes" problem

my rationale for Wed is to allow Thu and Fri for professional devs and Sat and Sun for hobbyists to test it, and Mon/Tue/Wed for us to work on patches
Yeah, I am a little uncertain -- I think it could do some good to publish a post just asking for beta testing mid-cycle once in the upcoming cycle would be good
I think we could try to push it back
It'll be a bit more pain with the usual last minute backports
but that's what we're trying to avoid
this shouldn't be usual
we always -- for basically the last 2-3 years -- have 3-4 last minute backports
and, much more rarely, some backports after the monday/tuesday promotion

simulacrum said:

It'll be a bit more pain with the usual last minute backports

there will be a cycle where it happens, but I would expect us to also shift beta/nightly back along with the pre-release, so like there won't be less time to work on backports after the first cycle
just because we have done that for a long time, doesn't mean it's not a point of risk -- and stress!
I mean, sure, but I don't know what you want to do about it -- moving dates isn't going to change the pace of development and backports, I expect
we take these steps to hopefully catch things before last minute, and raise the bar on what we accept so late
I don't object to taking these steps
but I don't believe they will let us avoid backports at the last minute
we usually ship several slipping regressions
anyway, I guess we can try
is there anything else folks would like to bring up?

I also feel like we had a few things that were like "mark will remember to do this before release" -- I mean no offense to you, but were these tracked in some visible/shared way? like the state of disabling incremental, I didn't know the plan on that
there was an issue filed and tracked as p-critical
does that show up on a project board?
uh, no, but we don't use those for anything. it shows up on the milestone, though
https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/milestone/81
https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/86004
(closed now so not on the list)
so ok, that tracks what we need to do, but not how/when we'll do it. I ended up raising this in chat because I feared it was slipping, to find out that your plan was to do it in stable promotion.
It's part of my routine at least to check the milestone during promotion
it's also true that was discussed, with Felix for example, though not logged on the issue (seems like it would have been good to do so, though I don't think it's of great importance)
suppose you were incapacitated -- would others know what to do?
(if others feel I'm making much ado about nothing, please say so)
imo, going through all milestoned issues should be the expected practice
certainly we can document that more, but I think as much as we can, the answer is yes
without context, that issue was P-critical without action for 10 days
This is not uncommon for p-critical issues, tbh
it was specifically discussed that we would backport in the stable promotion
we wanted to keep beta clean of that patch
so, that's fine, and I'm not really trying to litigate that particular issue. more that I don't feel the whole release team is kept aware if these things aren't clearly communicated.
maybe it's just me
and we're also out of time
it's certainly my impression that most of the release team did not want to be kept carefully informed of these things
if that's wrong, then we should work towards making that happen more consistently
yeah, let's call it for today, but I'm happy to chat with you individually @cuviper or we can continue next week (or otherwise).
Thanks everyone!

simulacrum said:

it's also true that was discussed, with Felix for example, though not logged on the issue (seems like it would have been good to do so, though I don't think it's of great importance)

I guess I'd put the emphasis here, it is important

hm, well, not sure I completely agree - it was discussed publicly in a compiler meeting on the topic of the incr bugs, IIRC, and agreement was reached there. We can work to reflect things on issues, but these things necessarily add overhead, and right now it does not seem that the overhead is entirely necessary -- the steps would be the same for the release regardless of when the force env patch was backported, and backporting it would be natural step to closing out that issue
if I disappeared, it could have been done earlier and that would be OK too

I don't agree that it's overhead. In this case, it caused extra confusion because even Felix didn't seem to remember that plan when I asked about it. He was ready to jump on it at my request, but I was missing information.
it was not a big deal, but that's what got me thinking about how we're sharing information
(and whether I had missed that information somewhere)
I see it now in the compiler meeting archive, but that would have been good to call out in the issue
that's all -- we don't need to belabor this further
